Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2012
Award.AbstractNarration:
The ecology of host-vector-pathogen interactions and tick borne disease risk

There is growing recognition that changes in host community ecology and interactions in the food chain can contribute to the emergence of infectious diseases. Many diseases cycle within a single species or area, but are transmitted to humans from their wildlife host either by direct contact, or more often by an arthropod vector. Because most infectious pathogens which can be transmitted across species are harbored by wildlife that occupy low levels in the food chain (particularly rodents), predation of these hosts may be critical to disease suppression. However, this is not well understood. A familiar case of disease emergence that is driven by changes in the host community is Lyme disease-the most prevalent vector-borne disease in North
America. The increases in Lyme disease in the northeastern and midwestern USA over the past three decades coincide with a range-wide decline of a key small mammal predator, the red fox, likely due to expansion of coyote populations. This research explores the hypothesis that changes in predator community structure have facilitated the emergence of Lyme disease by sampling the abundance and infection prevalence of the vector and host community in fox-dominated and coyote-dominated sites and by incorporating predation and vertebrate community structure into disease models.

The postdoctoral fellow will develop expertise in laboratory techniques to assay vector and hosts for pathogen infection, as well as statistical and analytical techniques for modeling the ecological drivers of infectious disease. The results of this research may have profound policy implications regarding how wildlife is managed while accounting for public health considerations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This NSF Postdoctoral Research Fellowship supported research on the ecology of tick-borne pathogens. Through this award we evaluated the characteristics of vertebrate hosts that make them good pathogen reservoirs. The abundance of such hosts can increase disease risk to humans. We found support for two hypotheses. First, hosts with fast life histories are more likely to be good disease reservoirs, meaning that they breed quickly after birth, breed frequently, and have large litters. Second, hosts that encounter vectors most frequently are likely to be good reservoirs, supporting the idea that pathogens evolve to specialize on hosts that they are most likely to contact.  This research sought to find general patterns that make some animals good disease hosts while others are not.

 

Our research also used twenty years of data assess how the timing of tick life stage activity in Dutchess County, New York depends on climate, and we projected this activity schedule into the future. We found that multiple tick life stages advance at a similar pace, which implies that in the next few decades we are unlikely to see larval and nymphal ticks active at the same time at a higher frequency. This has consequences for human disease because increased overlap favors transmission of Anaplasma and the very dangerous Powassan virus, while less overlap favors transmission of the Lyme bacterium. Cold areas that currently have larva-nymph activity overlap are likely to see less overlap in the future, potentially reducing the risk of Anaplasma or Powassan virus transmission. In addition, our research suggests that humans must be vigilant earlier in the year because the peak of nymph activity, the most dangerous tick life stage, is moving into early May.

 

Ticks and their pathogens are influenced by the abundance of key vertebrate hosts. Mice, in particular, are very likely to infect ticks that feed on them. Mouse populations currently outbreak in response to acorn crops, with consequence for tick abundance and infection prevalence, which determines disease risk, the following year. We discovered that small changes in predation rates may not initially produce a large change in prey (i.e. mouse) abundance, but can set these prey on different trajectories in response to a pulse of food availability (i.e. acorns). This research highlights a potential tipping point where a small change in predator abundance or diversity can allow prey populations to reach extraordinary numbers, which then increases disease risk to humans.

 

In an additional research project, we used empirical data and mathematical models to explore the relationship between biodiversity and disease risk. We found that the removal of some species, notably mice, chipmunks, or two species of shrews, can greatly reduce disease risk. However, removal of opossums and squirrels can greatly increase disease risk. Opossums and squirrels are good for our health, but small mammals are not. Most other species are inconsequential. Species that reduce the abundance of small mammals, such as their competitors or predators, are also likely to be benefit human health.
